channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: An aide to New York City's mayor gave a reporter a bag of money disguised as chips
item.description: This story starts with a bag of potato chips â€” but there were no chips inside. A city hall reporter was handed an empty bag with a red envelope filled with money from someone working for Mayor Eric Adams' re-election campaign. NPR's Juana Summers speaks to Katie Honan, the reporter at the center of the incident, about what happened.

item.title: Coastal flooding expected to continue in N.C. as Hurricane Erin moves out
item.description: North Carolina is starting to take stock of the impact the winds and waves from Hurricane Erin have had on its coastline that's already dealing with massive erosion.

item.title: A newscaster takes us along on her date with an AI companion
item.description: Despite dating apps and social media advice, romantic connections can be hard to make. Enter artificial intelligence.

item.title: What the 'KPop Demon Hunters' and 'Waiting to Exhale' soundtracks have in common
item.description: This week on the pop music charts, a film soundtrack has done something that no other soundtrack had done in nearly 30 years.

item.title: What's behind the trend of so-called 'gray divorces'?
item.description: What's behind the trend of so-called "gray divorces," and what is it like for newly single people to seek out new relationships over the age of 50?

item.title: A new study challenges what we know about how amputation alters the human brain
item.description: Even years after a person has lost an arm, the brain faithfully maintains the circuits that once controlled the missing limb.

item.title: This week in science: chocolate, daytime drowsiness and seabirds' bathroom habits
item.description: NPR's Hannah Chinn and Emily Kwong talk about the microbes behind great-tasting chocolate, possible reasons for daytime drowsiness, and a curious observation about the poop of seabirds.

item.title: Hurricane science has come leaps and bounds since Katrina. The progress is now at risk
item.description: Climate change increased the severity of Hurricane Katrina 20 years ago. Since the scientific understanding of how climate change influences hurricanes has changed and improved.

item.title: At 83 years old, Harrison Ford is still experiencing firsts
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. Harrison Ford talks about being too belligerent to listen to advice in his youth.

item.title: Singer-songwriter Kathleen Edwards on new album and her definition of 'Billionaire'
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to singer and songwriter Kathleen Edwards about her new album, Billionaire.
